values.alignmentText: Wild taiga and lake districts are beautiful, yet pollution around industrial hubs limits easy weekend escapes.
Permafrost melt, Siberian wildfires, and volatile harvests signal rising climate risk.
Winters plunge well below freezing and summers swing hot, far from the family’s mild-climate goal.
Major cities regularly exceed PM limits due to coal heat and traffic, though coastal and northern towns fare better.
Flooding, wildfires, and thawing permafrost threaten infrastructure in multiple regions.
Around 0–10°C (32–50°F) with lingering snow and muddy thaw.
Moscow and Saint Petersburg average 20–26°C (68–79°F) but heatwaves now top 32°C (90°F).
Cool 5–10°C (41–50°F) with early frosts and shortening daylight.
Extended stretches below -10°C (14°F) demand heavy gear and limit outdoor family time.
Beaches mainly on the distant Black Sea; limited access from central cities.
Black Sea peaks near 20–24°C (68–75°F) in summer, but season is short.
Dramatic mountains, lakes, and tundra offer striking scenery for adventurous families.
Regional minimums often sit under 20,000 RUB (~$220), insufficient for a four-person household.
Senior engineers may earn 2–3 million RUB annually, but currency controls complicate international pay.
Banks and state enterprises keep .NET roles available, yet most require in-country presence.
Ruby teams exist in e-commerce, but many companies relocated talent after 2022.
US citizens face severe scrutiny; few employers will undertake sponsorship amid geopolitical tension.
Sanctions and wartime spending warp the economy, limiting entrepreneurial stability.
Broadband is fast in cities, but VPNs are required for many Western services and censorship is tightening.
Tech teams often expect late hours during releases, and vacation can be curtailed by staffing pressures.
Standard 40‑hour week with overtime common in private sector.
Employees receive at least 28 days plus public holidays, supporting extended travel.
Many staff take the legal minimum, and managers sometimes discourage long absences.
Major metros move fast with long commutes; only smaller regional cities offer slower rhythms.
Schools run 8:30–14:30 and parents often extend days with extracurriculars to cover childcare gaps.
Families split time between city parks and dachas, though political rallies can disrupt public events.
Strong extended-family ties yet conservative expectations around roles.
Non‑monogamous relationships lack legal recognition and face social disapproval.
Traditional gendered roles prevail, with heavy emphasis on discipline.
Playgrounds exist but infrastructure is aging and car-heavy.
Public schools vary widely in quality; expat or private schools mainly in major cities.
State kindergartens have long waitlists, pushing families toward costly private options.
Some subsidies and maternity capital, but bureaucracy is high.
Foreign families rarely qualify for benefits and face registration hurdles.
Guaranteed enrollment though quality differs regionally.
Possible with proper permits but documentation can be burdensome.
International schools exist in major hubs but are expensive and few.
Pronatalist incentives like tax breaks exist yet favor traditional households.
Most benefits exclude non-citizens, leaving expat families with minimal support.
Numerous universities with strong STEM but variable pedagogy.
Foreign students may enroll but visas and language exams add friction.
Society stresses conventional male breadwinner and female caregiver roles.
Trans and nonbinary identities face legal and social suppression.
Domestic violence laws are weak and pay gaps persist.
Expectations around appearance and motherhood remain strong.
Cultural emphasis on toughness and military service influences male roles.
Rich literary tradition and unique art scenes may appeal to culture-seeking families.
Outside international firms, daily life requires Russian for paperwork and social integration.
State ideology leans nationalist and socially conservative, clashing with the family’s progressive values.
Post-Soviet nostalgia persists, but Marxism has little policy impact.
Secularism coexists with a resurgence of Orthodox Christianity.
Public discourse is reserved and sex education sparse.
Broad anti-"propaganda" laws criminalize queer visibility, making it unsafe for polyamory-positive families.
Neighborhood networks are close-knit but can be wary of outspoken foreigners.
Strong national pride and sense of exceptionalism.
Relations range from alliance to open conflict, reflecting geopolitical tensions.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Many neighbors harbor mistrust due to recent aggression.
Vibrant clubs and late-night cafes thrive in big cities despite social conservatism.
Styles mix sporty casual with formal suits in urban centers.
Urban women often embrace European chic and high heels.
Ice skating, soccer, and dacha gardening are widespread pastimes.
Niche communities exist but access to new imports is limited by sanctions.
Strong electronic and classical scenes offer varied evening options.
Tech meetups occur in major cities but many organizers have emigrated.
Forests and parks abound, yet distances and transport can be challenging.
Power concentrates in the presidency with managed elections and limited opposition.
Orthodox Church wields soft power in social policy debates.
Labor laws exist but enforcement is inconsistent, especially for migrants.
Nationalist rhetoric emphasizes sovereignty over liberal values.
Ongoing crackdowns on media and NGOs show active democratic erosion.
Oligarchic capitalism concentrates wealth and limits entrepreneurship.
Institutions appear stable but mobilization and war-related sanctions create daily uncertainty.
State media dominates news and shapes public opinion.
Narratives stress Western hostility and patriotic duty.
Benefits prioritize traditional families and military service over inclusive support.
Polling shows reported trust, yet it’s shaped by state media and limited alternatives.
Russia ranks near the bottom globally, with corruption embedded in many transactions.
Bribes and patronage networks influence everything from courts to utilities.
Renovated flats in safe districts command high prices, while Soviet-era blocks need costly upgrades.
Street crime is moderate, but arbitrary policing and political risk add stress.
Universal coverage struggles with staffing shortages and outdated equipment outside flagship hospitals.
Expats rely on private clinics for quality care and often plan for evacuation insurance.
Public kindergartens exist but have waitlists, especially in major cities.
Government incentives encourage larger families yet overlook diverse structures.
STEM instruction is strong, yet civic curriculum emphasizes state narratives that conflict with progressive values.
Moscow and Saint Petersburg boast efficient metros, though regional coverage is patchier.
State-owned giants and sanctions limit competition and access to Western markets.
Flat income tax keeps filing simple, but currency controls and reporting rules complicate expat finances.
Residents pay 13–15% income tax, yet double-tax treaties and sanctions make compliance tricky.
Domestic cards and QR payments work, but international transfers and cards remain heavily restricted.
Groceries and transit stay affordable, while imported goods and tuition have spiked.
Pension system faces funding gaps and rising retirement ages.
Foreign residents generally ineligible for state pensions.
Investor and work visas exist on paper, yet approvals for US applicants are exceedingly rare.
US citizens face heightened scrutiny amid strained relations.
Temporary residence requires employer or family sponsorship and strict annual reporting.
Naturalization generally demands five years, Russian fluency, and loyalty oaths, with security vetting.
Dependents can join but face registration, schooling, and healthcare hurdles.
Processing can take months with fees for translations and registrations.
Registration lapses, political speech, or visa technicalities can trigger fines or deportation.
Permitted but citizens must notify authorities and may face obligations.
Expect travel restrictions, data monitoring, and difficulties accessing Western platforms for work.
Studios operate, but sanctions limit publishing and many peers have relocated.
Teams like Gaijin and Saber keep Russian branches, though leadership often sits abroad.
Meetups persist but are smaller due to emigration and censorship concerns.
Access to capital and global distribution is severely limited under sanctions.
Urban infrastructure remains modern, yet import bans create maintenance challenges and rural gaps.
